713610f-a.text:
52nd Street, Broadway to 6th Avenue, front of #147.
(Before Reconstruction).
President Borough of Manhattan
November 23, 1921.

718184f.text:
A general view, north from 52nd Street, between Sixth and Seventh Aves., showing all of Central Park, with Fifth Ave. on the right and Central Park West on the left. At the extreme West is seen a small portion of the Hudson River.

1929.
Ewing Galloway.
718184f.folder: Central Park from 52nd Street & 6th Avenue, Manhattan, NY
718184f.original_title: Manhattan: Central Park from 52nd Street - 6th Avenue

713609f-a.text:
52nd Street, north side, west from Sixth Ave.
September 28, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

713612f-a.text:
West 52nd Street, east from (No. 115) a point between Seventh and Sixth Aves., showing the entrance to an automobile parking space on the south side of the street (right). Also shown is a portion of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line.
March 30, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

713613f-a.text:
West 52nd Street, south side, between Sixth and Seventh Aves., showing an automobile parking space, as it extends southward to West 50th Street after crossing West 51st Street. In the background appears, in silhouette, the Empire State Building, on the west side of Fifth Ave., from West 34th to West 33rd Streets.
March 30, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

713608f-b.text:
West 52nd Street, east across Sixth Avenue, showing the well known 52nd Street restaurant and night club district. Adjacent to both Times Square and Rockefeller City, it provides intimate entertainment to the cafe society group. It is lodged in the row of former private residences that extend between Sixth and Fifth Avenue's and are the direct result of the Prohibition era, being comparable to the Speakeasy of that day. Leon & Eddie's is the best known.
August 3, 1940
No's. 1-2
P. L. Sperr

713608f-a.text:
West 52nd Street, east across Sixth Avenue, showing the well known 52nd Street restaurant and night club district. Adjacent to both Times Square and Rockefeller City, it provides intimate entertainment to the cafe society group. It is lodged in the row of former private residences that extend between Sixth and Fifth Avenue's and are the direct result of the Prohibition era, being comparable to the Speakeasy of that day. Leon & Eddie's is the best known.
August 3, 1940
No's. 1-2
P. L. Sperr

713606f-b.text:
(1)
61 to 69 West 52nd Street, adjoining, and at the N.E. corner of Sixth Ave., showing No. 61-67 as a cleared area after the demolition of a 5-story house, and No. 69 in the process of being dismantled. Also shown is a portion of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line and across it a 6-story house, at the N.W. corner of Sixth Ave., bearing Nos. 1301-03
on the Avenue and 101 on West 52nd Street.
March 16, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, at a later date, and showing a more extensive view westward. No. 69, the 4-story building seen in view 1 is, at this time, completely demolished. Also shown (left to right) are Nos. 1301 to 1313 Sixth Ave., west side, north from and including West 52nd, to but not including West 53rd Streets.
June 9, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

713607f-c.text:
West 52nd Street, east from Sixth Avenue, as photographed during the subway constructional period on the latter thoroughfare. The buildings at the N. E. corner were removed to permit tunneling for the eastward curve to 53rd Street. The remaining former residences are now occupied by various restaurants and night clubs, and constitute a well known entertainment center for the cafe society group.
June 21, 1939
No's. 1-2-3
P. L. Sperr

713605f-a.text:
eew7
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 52nd to 53rd Streets, showing a clearance at the near corner. Under construction here is the underground bend in the 8th Avenue Subway. From this point it will run eastward under 53rd Street. Views 2 and 3 are limited to this feature. Overhead on the Avenue is the old "El" line. This will be torn down in 1938-9.
View 1,2: March 30, 1937
View 3: June 20, 1938
P. L. Sperr
